data.name: Main Stay Therapeutic Farm
data.description:
Main Stay’s mission is to enrich mind, body and spirit through powerful connections with horses, animals and nature.

Located in Richmond, IL, Main Stay is a non-profit organization that offers adaptive horseback riding, equine and animal-assisted learning activities and adaptive gardening programs to individuals with physical, developmental, behavioral, emotional and social challenges.

Main Stay enriches the lives of their clients in a caring, safe, and challenging environment that enables them to reach their full potential.

company_updates_collection.description:
Imagine hearing your child call you "mom" for the first time in 6 years... 

Read Erin's story, along with others you have helped support, in Main Stay's 2022 Annual Appeal: https://lnkd.in/gmd5Y5wf

Please join us in welcoming the newest member to Main Stay’s #boardofdirectors, Tom Gaughan!

Although new to the board, Tom is hardly new to Main Stay. He has been a dedicated volunteer in the adaptive riding program for the past 6 years. Tom started out as a sidewalker and is currently a horse handler. His quiet, calm demeanor in the arena helps both horses and riders stay focused and safe. 

Tom brings a strong financial leadership background to the board which will be a tremendous asset to Main Stay. He has long career in the financial services industry and was Managing Partner and majority owner of a successful brokerage company which specialized in hedging futures for the dairy industry. Although he sold his company to a publicly traded firm over 10 years ago and “retired”, Tom continues to do consulting work.

We are so excited and grateful to have Tom join our team. His passion for Main Stay’s mission combined with his financial acumen makes Tom an ideal addition to the board of directors.

Last year, Main Stay provided services to over 500 individuals through our equine and animal assisted learning programs which was only possible through your generous support.  

On this Giving Tuesday, please consider making a gift to Main Stay. Just imagine all the good it will do. https://lnkd.in/eVcaPHQ2

Clients, volunteers and staff gathered this past Saturday to celebrate rider accomplishments and to recognize our fantastic volunteers' contributions. Riders received certificates of achievement and everyone received their year-end gift, a t-shirt with our beautiful Many Hearts One Farm logo. A year-end slide show, photo opportunity with one of the Main Stay animals, music by Austin Cheberenchick, a former rider and current volunteer, and lunch rounded out the event. 

Every year one volunteer is chosen for the Founder's Award, an award that recognizes someone who exemplifies the Main Stay values of caring, integrity, team work, safety, accepting, quality and respect. This year's winner was Wendy Marchel. Wendy has volunteered at Main Stay for 20 years and has helped in all the volunteer roles including leading, grooming and sidewalking along with assisting the Equine Manager when searching for program horses. As an Equine Massage Therapist, Wendy also helps our horses feel their best. Wendy truly is a gift to the program and we so appreciate her many talents!

The party is a great way to wrap up the year and it was especially wonderful this year to be together in person after not being able to do that for the past two years. We're proud of our riders and so grateful to our volunteers, we have a great community here at the farm!

#ThrowbackThursday | From Boarding Barn to Therapeutic Farm

More than 35 years ago, Sara Foszcz was a bright-eyed young woman running a boarding/show barn for horses – unaware of the incredible journey Main Stay would soon lead her on. 

Today, Sara takes a look back on an experience that played a pivotal role in her founding of Main Stay in 1987, and reminds us of the magic that happens when we choose to see individuals for their abilities, rather than disabilities. Read Sara's story here: https://lnkd.in/gesiHAz2

Congratulations to our instructor, Sarah, on achieving her Certified Therapeutic Riding Instructor (CTRI) certification! 

Sarah started with us as a volunteer several years ago and her passion for adaptive riding encouraged her to make it her new profession (along with being a mom of 2!) Certification requires having a thorough knowledge of horses and people along with demonstrating teaching ability. It's an intensive process that can take a year or more to complete. We are thrilled to have Sarah on our teaching team!

Thank you for voting Main Stay's 2022 Gala as "One of the Best Fundraising Events" in this year’s McHenry County Best of the Fox Reader’s Choice Awards! 

We also want to thank our generous sponsors who made the event possible and our guests who helped to make it a record-breaking event for Main Stay! 

#fundraising #events

Calling all Girl Scouts! 
 
Did you know troops can earn a variety of patches and badges at Main Stay for all levels of scouts? The farm offers a place to learn about inclusion and acceptance, animals, nature, gardening, leadership and more. Horseback Riding, Flowers, Gardener, Trees, Animal Helpers and Voice for Animals are just some of the badges that can be accomplished in one or more visits. Working with the animals and being outdoors is a great way to grow. 

Reach out to Jean Maraist at jmaraist@mainstayfarm.org or 815-653-9374 to discuss availability and cost.

#girlscouts #leadership #inclusion

As some of you may know, Main Stay has been actively #recruiting  new members for our #boardofdirectors for the past several months. We are pleased to share that we have identified someone who we believe is a great addition and complement the other members of this team. Please join us in welcoming Jorge Arza to Main Stay's Board of Directors.

Jorge is currently the Regional Director of Operations for Starbucks and oversees roughly 110 stores in the northern Illinois and southern Wisconsin area. In his role, Jorge specializes in creative problem solving and building strong teams. He is also a lifelong equestrian and he and his son ride with Woodwind Farm in McHenry. Jorge's unique combination of collaborative management and equestrian experience make him a great addition to our board.

Jorge and his family reside in Crystal Lake.

We are very grateful that Jorge said yes and will be joining our very dedicated and dynamic team here at Main Stay. 

Welcome Jorge!

Thanks to everyone who has contributed to the 2022 Riders' Challenge and to Huemann Water Conditioning for generously sponsoring the riders' t-shirts! A little over $8,000 has been raised so far! Your generosity will help our special herd receive the care they need along with funds to purchase a new therapy horse. With expenses increasing in all areas, your contributions are especially appreciated!

It was a great three weeks of learning and riders received ribbons during the last week of the Challenge celebrating their accomplishments. We are still short of our goal of $15,000. It's not too late to donate on our website at www.mainstayfarm.org or to a rider through their Facebook fundraiser or directly to them. Thanks for your support of our hard working horses!

#donate

New year, new program horse! 
King is our newest addition to the Main Stay equine team! He is a big, beautiful, gentle Percheron gelding that seems to enjoy his new life at the farm. Main Stay needs horses of all shapes and sizes to accommodate the wide range of clients we serve so we are very grateful to be able to add King to our program. He will continue his training this winter along with being part of the winter session lessons. 

Welcome King, we are excited to have you on the Team!

Imagine hearing your child call you "mom" for the first time in 6 years...

We’re #hiring. Know anyone who might be interested?

We need volunteers! 

Are you interested, or do you know someone who is interested in learning more about volunteering? Please join us for the 2023 Volunteer Tour & Info Session on Monday, February 20th, 4-5 pm. Come tour the farm, watch a class, see the animals and learn about available volunteer roles. Our programs rely on dedicated and caring volunteers! Experienced horse people are especially needed. 

RSVP by Thursday, February 17th to reserve your spot: https://lnkd.in/d9cZYZfZ

For more information, contact the Volunteer Coordinator at vc@mainstayfarm.org or call / text 815-382-9374.

#volunteer

Main Stay is kicking off its new monthly giving program, the Giving Hearts Community, in time for you to help spread the love this Valentine's Day! Starting now thru February 14, honor someone special (including yourself!) by becoming a monthly donor at Main Stay and we will send them a personalized Valentine's Day e-card!

To learn more about the Giving Hearts Community or to view our selection of e-cards, please visit https://lnkd.in/gAQTgjVS

If you have any questions about becoming a monthly donor, or are already a monthly donor and would like a Valentine's Day e-card sent, please contact Randi at rmurawski@mainstayfarm.org or give us a call at 815-653-9374

We are excited to announce two Main Stay team members were recently recognized by PATH Intl. (Professional Association of Therapeutic Horsemanship International) as the Volunteer of the Year and Equine of the Year for Region 7!

Cathy Farrell was awarded the Volunteer of The Year Award which is presented annually to an individual whose dedicated contributions are of the highest quality and has helped enhance the ability of the organization to provide equine- assisted services through a long history of volunteer service. Cathy exemplifies these attributes through her more than 14 years of dedicated service to Main Stay! She volunteers in a number of roles at the farm and works with a wide variety of clients in both the adaptive riding and animal assisted learning programs. 

Main Stay’s Norwegian Fjord horse, Kay, was named Region 7 Equine of the Year. Kay was chosen for the outstanding work she has performed here at the farm for the past
10 years. Her steadfast and kind nature, make her the first choice for riders who require a high level of support. Kay’s quiet and gentle demeanor brings a sense of calm to all who interact with her.

Regional winners will be acknowledged on February 18, 2023 in Sherrard, Illinois with a national winner chosen at the 2023 PATH Intl. International Conference in October, 2023. Good luck to Cathy and Kay!

PATH Intl. leads the advancement of professional equine-assisted services by supporting members and stakeholders through rigorously developed standards, credentialing and education. PATH Intl.’s Region 7 covers the geographic region of Illinois, Iowa, Nebraska, Kansas and Missouri.

Thank you for your generous support!

We need #volunteers! 

Are you or someone you know interested in learning more about volunteering? Please join us for the 2023 Volunteer Tour & Info Session on Saturday, May 20th at 10-11am. Come tour the farm, watch a class, see the animals and learn about available volunteer roles. Our programs rely on dedicated and caring volunteers! Experienced horse people are especially needed. 

To reserve your spot, please visit: https://lnkd.in/gJzX4MvA

Thanks to Eileen from Freedom of Motion Equine and Saddle Services for sharing her #expertise with us! As a Society of Master Saddlers Qualified Saddle Fitter, Eileen assists us in ensuring that our saddles fit our herd. Well-fitting saddles are essential to the horses' welfare, and her generous donation of time is so appreciated. 

We are getting ready for our Spring/Summer session which begins next week!

Native plants are crucial to our local ecosystems because they provide food and shelter to many species of birds and insects. Main Stay strives to work in partnership with our surrounding environment and we have many native plant varieties in the flower beds around the building. 

Today, Small Waters Education NFP came to the farm to teach us more about how to maintain and care for these plants. We cut down stalks for insects to shelter in, identified native and invasive plant species, removed many invasive praying mantis egg cases, and spread milkweed seeds. Thank you to Small Waters Education and to our wonderful garden volunteers for helping us care for our environment!

Educator Appreciation Day at the Farm | Saturday, May 6

As Teacher Appreciation Week approaches, we want to celebrate all hard-working school personnel! Join us at our beautiful 40-acre farm, in Richmond, for some self-care and family fun! Bring yourself or your family and spend time together in nature. 

REGISTRATION REQUIRED.

April is a BIG anniversary month at Main Stay! ? 
 
✨ Congratulations to Jean, Director of Programming & Community Engagement who is celebrating 25 years with Main Stay!

✨ A big shout out to Art, Main Stay's Farm Manager who has been with us for 15 years!

✨ Happy 8th anniversary to Tina, Adaptive riding instructor extraordinaire!
 
✨ And although she wasn't here to be in the photo, Brooke, who helps care for our animals, is celebrating her 1 year anniversary this month!

Wow--a collective 49 years of dedicated service--we are very grateful to you all! ?
Bald eagle spotted at Glacial Park yesterday morning. We certainly have the best views!

A big shout out to an awesome volunteer group from Starbucks who spent several hours helping at the farm! 

This hardworking bunch helped us accomplish some big "to do" items on our list including painting the "littles" sheds, clean up work as we prepare for our upcoming gala and painting this beautiful butterfly which will hang in our new "Littles Lodge" in the north arena. Their time and energy are so appreciated! They also brought some delicious coffee to share. ?☕

Thank you! ?

#volunteersmakeadifference #volunteers

Meet Kelly, a young student with a heart of gold! ? 

When she participated in her school's "Made by Me Market," selling handmade bracelets that she and her mom made, Kelly knew she wanted to do more than just sell them for profit. She decided to donate her earnings to Main Stay Therapeutic Farm. 

"I love all the animals there, and Main Stay always helps everyone who has a chance to ride or visit the farm. I know how important it is to my grandma, Cathy, and I wanted to help keep it growing," says Kelly. Her grandma, Cathy, is a Main Stay volunteer and was just recently awarded the 2023 Region 7 Volunteer of the Year Award from PATH Intl. 

This isn't the first time Kelly has made a difference for a good cause though. She previously helped her grandpa raise money for Ronald McDonald House Charities during the Chicago Marathon. 

Kelly's story is a shining example of the power we all have to make a positive difference, and reminds us that even the smallest act can make a significant impact. ✨ 

#makeadifference #philanthropy

Native plants are crucial to our local ecosystems because they provide food and shelter to many species of birds and insects. Main Stay strives to work in partnership with our surrounding environment and we have many native plant varieties in the flower beds around the building. 

Today, Small Waters Education NFP came to the farm to teach us more about how to maintain and care for these plants. We cut down stalks for insects to shelter in, identified native and invasive plant species, removed many invasive praying mantis egg cases, and spread milkweed seeds. Thank you to Small Waters Education and to our wonderful garden volunteers for helping us care for our environment!

Educator Appreciation Day at the Farm | Saturday, May 6

As Teacher Appreciation Week approaches, we want to celebrate all hard-working school personnel! Join us at our beautiful 40-acre farm, in Richmond, for some self-care and family fun! Bring yourself or your family and spend time together in nature.

Meet Kelly, a young student with a heart of gold! ? 

When she participated in her school's "Made by Me Market," selling handmade bracelets that she and her mom made, Kelly knew she wanted to do more than just sell them for profit. She decided to donate her earnings to Main Stay Therapeutic Farm. 

"I love all the animals there, and Main Stay always helps everyone who has a chance to ride or visit the farm. I know how important it is to my grandma, Cathy, and I wanted to help keep it growing," says Kelly. Her grandma, Cathy, is a Main Stay volunteer and was just recently awarded the 2023 Region 7 Volunteer of the Year Award from PATH Intl. 

This isn't the first time Kelly has made a difference for a good cause though. She previously helped her grandpa raise money for Ronald McDonald House Charities during the Chicago Marathon. 

Kelly's story is a shining example of the power we all have to make a positive difference, and reminds us that even the smallest act can make a significant impact. ✨

Spirit, who looks like his namesake from the movie, is our newest member of the herd! He's a 13 year old Missouri Fox Trotter, a type of gaited riding horse that is very comfortable to ride. He has a kind and willing personality and a nice height and build for carrying a wide variety of our riders. 

Mr. Sparks, the agency staff member who attends sessions with clients from Banner Learning, had the opportunity to help with his training today! Fridays are for baking bread! 

Our Volunteer Coordinator Monica taught McHenry summer school students how to bake bread from scratch using her very own "ridiculously easy overnight bread" recipe! Monica even had a fresh loaf already made for the students to try.

Following the steps in a recipe, taking turns and sharing equipment develops social skills in a friendly setting. Making homemade bread increases awareness of where food comes from and can encourage healthy eating choices and trying new things. Getting to sample warm bread fresh from the oven is the best part!

#BakingBread #SocialEmotionalSkills

July is Disability Pride Month and commemorates the passage of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), a landmark civil rights law signed on July 26, 1990. At Main Stay, our core values have always revolved around acceptance and inclusion. We believe that embracing the uniqueness of every person creates a world of beautiful possibilities. We invite you to join us in celebrating Disability Pride Month at the farm this week! As a special treat, we're offering cupcakes, colorful macaroons and disability pride stickers, located next to our diversity board in the Gathering Room.

We are excited to announce that Main Stay has earned a Four-Star Rating for the 8th consecutive year, and a 100% Perfect Score for the second time by Charity Navigator, the largest and most-utilized independent charity evaluator in America. 

Charity Navigator defines a charity with a 4-star rating as one who “exceeds or meets best practices and industry standards across almost all areas and likely to be a highly-effective charity.” Because of this impeccable rating, Main Stay has been designated as an official “Give with Confidence” charity.
 
Charity Navigator analyzes nonprofit performance based on four key indicators or “beacons”. Nonprofits can earn scores for the Accountability & Finance, Culture & Community, Leadership & Adaptability, and Impact & Results beacons. Each beacon represents an area of organizational performance that can influence nonprofit success. Main Stay’s performance was evaluated for and earned a 100% score in the Accountability & Finance, Culture & Community, and Leadership & Adaptability beacons. Charity Navigator has not yet established methodology to rate Equine and Animal-assisted services programs for Impact & Results, which is the 4th beacon, therefore Main Stay is not eligible for this rating as of now. You can learn more about Charity Navigator’s methodology and our rating at https://lnkd.in/dMQj6aa8
 
Importantly, we want to express our deepest gratitude to you, our incredible supporters. Without your continued trust and support, none of this would have been possible. YOU are an essential part of the Main Stay family, and your involvement has a profound impact on the lives of the individuals we serve. Together, we can continue to enrich the mind, body, and spirit of individuals through powerful connections with horses, animals, and nature.
 
Once again, thank you for your dedicated support, your belief in our mission, and your belief in Main Stay. ?

Main Stay is beyond grateful to be 1 of the 35 non-profit organizations selected to receive this generous grant!  

Compeer Financial's Fund for Rural America is a corporate giving program of Compeer Financial, structured to support Compeer Financial's mission to enrich agriculture and rural America. The 2023 Riders' Challenge is underway and we hope you are as excited as rider Grace and volunteer Brittany are! 

Over the next 3 weeks, our riders will be raising funds to assist in purchasing another therapy horse and support the expenses with our current herd. Horses have been a large part of our culture and history for centuries and this year's theme, Horses in Stories, will explore mythology, movies and literature. One of the most famous horses in Greek mythology is Pegasus, the white, winged stallion. Pegasus carried the thunderbolts for Zeus, king of the gods and the stories say everywhere he stepped a natural water spring would appear.  During their lessons, riders will be riding the Pegasus constellation pattern, the 7th largest constellation in the northern sky!

Having a healthy and happy equine partner is essential to the riders' success and we are excited to see who raises the most money to support the herd! We welcome your support too! Sponsor a rider directly or donate to the challenge at https://lnkd.in/g_4Zvx5R

The 2023 Riders' Challenge T-shirts are generously sponsored by Platinum Terrain LLC.

Main Stay is thrilled to introduce the newest additions to our program: a fabulous family of four young guinea pigs! Mom, Petunia, and her 3 daughters, Violet, Tulip and Marigold needed a new home due to an unexpected twist in their previous owner’s story—a mix-up that led to an unplanned guinea pig family. Thankfully, Main Stay was able to welcome all the girls and their original owner happily kept the males.

Our little guinea pig family finds joy in interacting with each other, often engaging in spirited play that includes the endearing “zoomies” and joyful leaps known as “popcorning.” They’re currently adapting to our bustling barn within their snug habitat, but exciting plans are in the works. Facility manager Art is constructing a larger, specially designed “Piggie Palace” just for them, ensuring they have the perfect space to thrive.

Learn more about this furry family and the benefit they will bring to our Animal Assisted Learning program at https://lnkd.in/gp2PrjC3

Main Stay's Harness the Power of Your Team offers tailored team building and leadership sessions to any group that wants to experience a distinctive experiential learning opportunity. This week, McHenry High School Bridges program participated in a Harness the Power of Your Team Day at Main Stay.
 
Students and Bridges staff worked together in small groups with a focus on setting achievable goals, identifying personal strengths, cooperation and of course having a fun experience together. Bridges students range in age from 18 to 22 and are working on independent life skills to best prepare them for adult responsibilities. The program will do two more team building days later in the year in order to document personal growth throughout the school year.

Our customized activities, in collaboration with our animals, ignite inspiration among participants, fostering teamwork and goal achievement aligned with your organization's objectives. If you are interested in learning more, please contact Jean at jmaraist@mainstayfarm.org

#teambuilding #leadershipskills #goalsetting

As we welcome the start of autumn and say goodbye to summer, we are thrilled to share that with the use of our donated monarch enclosure, Main Stay has become certified as an official Monarch Way Station site by Monarch Watch —an education, conservation, and research initiative rooted at the University of Kansas. 

A Way Station contributes to monarch conservation by providing habitat and resources to help current and future generations of monarchs sustain their migration. Importantly, the monarch enclosure has been a wonderful addition to our Animal Assisted Learning program, affording students a unique opportunity to watch the transformation of butterflies through all four stages of metamorphosis and participating in their releases.

This vital conservation effort began last year when Roy and Mari-Jo Young graciously gifted Main Stay a custom-made monarch enclosure. Since then, our very own staff member LeAnn, and volunteer Amy have been dedicated to managing the enclosure and raising the monarchs, resulting in the release of over 100 butterflies just this year. Their diligent work involved egg collection, providing, and collecting milkweed plants, and cleaning of caterpillar frass. The natural landscaping in the front of our building provides plenty of milkweed and native plants to sustain both visiting and raised monarchs.

Our official status as a certified Monarch Way Station speaks to our dedication to protecting and preserving our beautiful 40-acre farm. This commitment enables us to continue enriching the lives of the individuals we serve by connecting them with the nature and creatures of our land. Moreover, thanks to the protection afforded by a land easement through the The Land Conservancy of McHenry County, our farm will remain a secure sanctuary for migrating monarchs, ensuring their well-being for both present and future generations to come.

As we welcome the start of autumn and say goodbye to summer, we are thrilled to share that with the use of our donated monarch enclosure, Main Stay has become certified as an official Monarch Way Station site by Monarch Watch —an education, conservation, and research initiative rooted at the University of Kansas. 

A Way Station contributes to monarch conservation by providing habitat and resources to help current and future generations of monarchs sustain their migration. Importantly, the monarch enclosure has been a wonderful addition to our Animal Assisted Learning program, affording students a unique opportunity to watch the transformation of butterflies through all four stages of metamorphosis and participating in their releases.

This vital conservation effort began last year when Roy and Mari-Jo Young graciously gifted Main Stay a custom-made monarch enclosure. Since then, our very own staff member LeAnn, and volunteer Amy have been dedicated to managing the enclosure and raising the monarchs, resulting in the release of over 100 butterflies just this year. Their diligent work involved egg collection, providing, and collecting milkweed plants, and cleaning of caterpillar frass. The natural landscaping in the front of our building provides plenty of milkweed and native plants to sustain both visiting and raised monarchs.

Our official status as a certified Monarch Way Station speaks to our dedication to protecting and preserving our beautiful 40-acre farm. This commitment enables us to continue enriching the lives of the individuals we serve by connecting them with the nature and creatures of our land. Moreover, thanks to the protection afforded by a land easement through the The Land Conservancy of McHenry County, our farm will remain a secure sanctuary for migrating monarchs, ensuring their well-being for both present and future generations to come.

We are excited to announce that Main Stay has earned a Four-Star Rating for the 8th consecutive year, and a 100% Perfect Score for the second time by Charity Navigator, the largest and most-utilized independent charity evaluator in America. 

Charity Navigator defines a charity with a 4-star rating as one who “exceeds or meets best practices and industry standards across almost all areas and likely to be a highly-effective charity.” Because of this impeccable rating, Main Stay has been designated as an official “Give with Confidence” charity.
 
Charity Navigator analyzes nonprofit performance based on four key indicators or “beacons”. Nonprofits can earn scores for the Accountability & Finance, Culture & Community, Leadership & Adaptability, and Impact & Results beacons. Each beacon represents an area of organizational performance that can influence nonprofit success. Main Stay’s performance was evaluated for and earned a 100% score in the Accountability & Finance, Culture & Community, and Leadership & Adaptability beacons. Charity Navigator has not yet established methodology to rate Equine and Animal-assisted services programs for Impact & Results, which is the 4th beacon, therefore Main Stay is not eligible for this rating as of now. You can learn more about Charity Navigator’s methodology and our rating at https://lnkd.in/dMQj6aa8
 
Importantly, we want to express our deepest gratitude to you, our incredible supporters. Without your continued trust and support, none of this would have been possible. YOU are an essential part of the Main Stay family, and your involvement has a profound impact on the lives of the individuals we serve. Together, we can continue to enrich the mind, body, and spirit of individuals through powerful connections with horses, animals, and nature.
 
Once again, thank you for your dedicated support, your belief in our mission, and your belief in Main Stay. ?

Scott Castell and Londa Lauber of Compeer Financial stopped by the farm this week to present Main Stay with a $5,000 general use grant through Compeer Financial's Fund for Rural America. Main Stay is beyond grateful to be 1 of the 35 non-profit organizations selected to receive this generous grant!  

Compeer Financial's Fund for Rural America is a corporate giving program of Compeer Financial, structured to support Compeer Financial's mission to enrich agriculture and rural America. Compeer Financial's Board of Directors has dedicated one percent of annual net earnings to support the Fund's focus areas of agricultural advocacy and development, agriculture education, cooperative initiatives, rural development and community enrichment; and youth engagement.

We are pleased and proud to share that Jean Maraist, Main Stay’s Director of Programming & Community Engagement, has been named PATH Intl. Credentialed Professional of the Year for Region 7! 

PATH Intl. (Professional Association for Therapeutic Horsemanship International) is the credentialing organization for equine-assisted services. Each year member centers can nominate a candidate and a winner is chosen from each region. Region 7 covers Illinois, Missouri, Kansas, Iowa, and Nebraska. The credentialed professional of the year must hold a PATH Intl. certification, demonstrate excellent teaching skills, show compassion and respect for participants and volunteers, demonstrates safe, humane and excellent horsemanship skills and adheres to all PATH Intl. standards and code of ethics.

Having been a certified adaptive riding instructor with Main Stay for more than 25 years, along with being a licensed occupational therapist and a lifelong equestrian, make Jean the perfect candidate for region 7 Professional of the Year. Jean has dedicated her life to helping individuals through equine-assisted services. She has not only helped Main Stay grow into the successful program it is today but also has been actively involved in educating individuals and expanding the reach and quality of equine-assisted services on a regional and national level. 

Regional winners will compete for the national title later in the year. 
No matter the outcome, Main Stay and its clients are the real winners who benefit from Jean’s dedication, hard work, and knowledge. 

Please join us in congratulating Jean on this well-deserved award!

There is no health without mental health. 

Dear Main Stay Friends,

We wanted to share some important information regarding the upcoming March 19 primary elections in McHenry County. There will be a referendum on the ballot which will remove the property tax levy for services provided by the Mental Health Board and add a county wide sales tax of .25% to fund these services. The McHenry County Board passed this referendum at the December meeting.

The sales tax levy would provide an additional $2MM (which is expected to grow), or a total of $12MM-$13MM annually, to the Mental Health Board which provides critical mental health, substance abuse, and disability services. If approved, the tax would take effect 7/1/2024 and property owners would see a decrease in property taxes in 2025.

McHenry County residents must register to vote no later than February 20, 2024 to vote in the March 19 General Primary Election. Voters do not need to declare a party to vote and can request a non-partisan referendum only ballot to cast a vote.

For more information on this important referendum, please go to: https://lnkd.in/gmat96ar

#mentalhealthmatters

On nice weather days, we ride outside! Here, Bowyn and Asher are on top of the hill in our outdoor sensory arena. Bowyn rides with the help of his leader Sue, and his side walkers, Lori and Carol.

Our outdoor sensory arena features a variety of tracks made from different materials, including sand, grass, deep sand, stones, a wooden bridge, and woodchips. Each surface creates different sounds and sensations for our riders as their horse walks over them. The materials can be picked up and felt, which is especially helpful when asking the rider to pick which tracks to walk over.

Additionally, the arena is equipped with a PVC tree at the center, complete with hanging rings for riders to reach and engage with. This outdoor setting not only enriches the sensory experience but also connects riders with their surroundings, allowing them to observe birds, airplanes, other horses, flowers and trees.

April is National Autism Acceptance Month! 

National Autism Acceptance Month aims to raise awareness, promote acceptance, and advocate for individuals with autism, fostering a more inclusive and understanding environment where they can thrive. Among those celebrated during this month is Main Stay’s very own, Jack!

Jack, who came to Main Stay as a rider over 15 years ago, is a person with autism and is seeking the same understanding as everyone else. He currently holds two part-time jobs, one of which is at Main Stay! Jack was hired at the farm in 2021 as a barn assistant and then in 2023 was promoted to facility maintenance. Jack, like many individuals, also experiences struggles with his mental health and finds value in our understanding culture:

Spring is here and that means it's time to prepare the garden! 

At Main Stay we have been hard at work collecting supplies needed to test the soil for our garden. Testing the soil involved collecting compost from the manure pile, adding water to the soil and then testing it into tubes. Mikki tested the soil to check the levels of phosphorus, nitrogen, and the pH levels. Testing the soil involves filling up the test tubes with the water that has separated from the compost and mixing it with a solution to see if the levels are surplus, sufficient, adequate, deficient, or depleted. 

It is important to test the levels of the nutrients in the soil to be sure that the vegetables and plants we choose for the upcoming season survive. Tomatoes, for instance, can be picky about the nitrogen in the soil and it is helpful to know levels for which type of tomato to plant. The soil that we tested will be used in our garden to grow our wildflowers, herbs, vegetables, and fruits. Testing the soil is an easy way to ensure your plants are happy and healthy for growing. Soil tests are easy to find at local garden centers or outdoor stores and are often inexpensive. 

Last week, Mikki, Karen, and Amy started the planting of our seeds, which already are sprouting! ? 

#grow #adaptivegarden

Thank you volunteers who joined us for a training session on May 1! 

We focused on how to safely move our horse partners in and out of paddocks and in and out of stalls. It all starts with observing and understanding horse behavior and being aware of what is happening in the environment around you and the horse. We took a deep dive into understanding the paddocks, the lane and the turnout board. 

Next, we practiced safely approaching horses in the paddocks, haltering them, and leading them through gates. Then we practiced safely moving into and out of stalls. After we turned the horses out again, we watched them interact with each other during feeding time. 

Our session ended with a visit with the Littles, where Petey wanted to be included in the group photo! ?

April is Occupational Therapy (OT) Month! 

OT Month celebrates the field and brings awareness to the crucial role OT professionals play in helping people of all ages achieve optimal performance in their daily life roles. Therapists work in a wide variety of settings including at the barn which provides a rich learning and sensory experience utilizing the movement of the horse to improve strength, balance, range of motion and more. 

This month some of the students from the McHenry County College Occupational Therapy Assistant program were at the farm for one of their fieldwork experiences!

Fieldwork provides a time for students to practice and apply skills such as clinical reasoning in a community-based learning setting along with time to interact with clients and caregivers in our adaptive riding program. Students also had a chance to assist Main Stay clients during some of the lessons which was a great hands-on learning experience. 

Helping future healthcare professionals grow in their professional careers and sharing the many benefits people receive through partnering with horses is something we are proud to be a part of in our community!

 #occupationaltherapy

On nice weather days, we ride outside! Here, Bowyn and Asher are on top of the hill in our outdoor sensory arena. Bowyn rides with the help of his leader Sue, and his side walkers, Lori and Carol.

Our outdoor sensory arena features a variety of tracks made from different materials, including sand, grass, deep sand, stones, a wooden bridge, and woodchips. Each surface creates different sounds and sensations for our riders as their horse walks over them. The materials can be picked up and felt, which is especially helpful when asking the rider to pick which tracks to walk over.

Additionally, the arena is equipped with a PVC tree at the center, complete with hanging rings for riders to reach and engage with. This outdoor setting not only enriches the sensory experience but also connects riders with their surroundings, allowing them to observe birds, airplanes, other horses, flowers and trees.

In the middle of September 2023, Carla and her EAAL group thought they had discovered a monarch caterpillar in our adaptive garden. Carla gave the caterpillar to LeAnn to ensure its safety over the winter. However, LeAnn quickly realized that it was not a monarch caterpillar but a black swallowtail caterpillar! ? 

LeAnn took the caterpillar home and researched its dietary needs. After a few days, the black swallowtail caterpillar formed its chrysalis. Unlike the usual 10-12 day emergence, this chrysalis had to overwinter. LeAnn carefully placed the chrysalis outside in a safe place for the winter.

As the weather warmed, LeAnn brought the chrysalis back to Main Stay and placed it in the monarch enclosure so our Monarch team could help keep an eye on it. For six weeks, we watched and waited. 

On May 15th, one of our EAAL groups noticed the chrysalis had darkened. The very next day, she emerged from her chrysalis! EAAL student Marcus named her "Colby," and she was released later that day. ? 

A big thank you to LeAnn for taking such good care of Colby!

Did you know that Main Stay is a registered Monarch Waystation? This means that we are a safe place for Monarch Butterflies to rest during their migration by maintaining a good habitat. Part of our goal in maintaining a good habitat for the butterflies includes our participation in the Illinois Monarch Pledge, where we have pledged to improve our native habitats and provide education on Monarch Butterflies. 

To continue our spread of education on environmental conservation, we were able to host a seminar with the McHenry County Conservation District on the Monarch Life Cycle! Participants learned about the journey and life cycle of Monarch Butterflies and were able to see how Main Stay helps to raise and release our own. 

Thank you, McHenry County Conservation District, for this opportunity and providing a great presentation!

Their playful antics and warm and friendly presence contribute to the nurturing environment we strive to create here at our farm. 

Thank you, Linus and Lucy, for the light you bring to the lives of everyone here at Main Stay! ?

In addition to our adaptive riding and horsemanship program, Main Stay offers shorter-term riding options for youth (ages 8-16) and active adults (55+) through our Saddle Up program. Each session lasts 4-6 weeks and includes groups of 3-4 participants who learn horsemanship and riding skills.

Our most recent session of Saddle Up had riders who are all Main Stay volunteers! The four weeks consisted of gaining knowledge and confidence in their abilities to get horses from the paddocks, groom them, tack them up, lead them around the arena, and ride. While Disability Pride Month is celebrated throughout July, today marks the 34th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). This landmark law prohibits discrimination against people with disabilities, paving the way for a more inclusive society, a great first step, however, there is still more work to be done. As we celebrate this day, it is crucial to recognize that discrimination and challenges still affect this diverse community. 

We hope you'll join us in continuing to create an environment where everyone feels valued and respected, recognizing the unique abilities that each individual brings and the beauty that emerges when those abilities shine. By working together, not just this month, but every month, we can help ensure that every person in our community is given the opportunity to thrive and the support to reach their highest potential.

#ADA34

Sometimes it is nice to have a change in class!

When rider Vinny is at the farm, he usually rides his adaptive riding horse, Lil Rusty, in a western saddle. Recently, when Harry subbed in for Lil Rusty, Vinny and his team chose a pad and a surcingle for a different type of riding lesson. He rode facing forward, lying down, sitting backwards, lying backwards, and sitting on his knees facing forward – without his usual saddle. The most exciting part, though, is that Vinny was able to receive more sensory input than he normally would riding in his saddle!

Diverse riding positions like this also help riders with their postural control on and off the horse, as well as enhance their motor skills!

We are in search of a part-time Barn Assistant to join our Main Stay team! 

As a part-time Barn Assistant, you'll play a crucial role in supporting the health, well-being and care of Main Stay’s herd of therapy animals (some pictured below!). We are seeking one or more individuals who are available to work various shifts including weekday mornings, evenings and weekends (10-15 hours/week). From feeding the animals and cleaning their stalls, to ensuring the barn is safe and well-maintained, you'll be instrumental in creating a respectful, positive and safe environment for both our animals and the individuals we serve.

The ideal candidate is a self-starter and excellent communicator, has keen observation skills and is committed to following safety protocols. A minimum of 5 years of horse handling experience is required. On a chillier morning in Spring, Leah came in for her lesson with Harry. Her dad mentioned she was listening to The Sound of Music in the car. So, we started listening to it in class, and her team was thrilled when she started to sing along! She was especially loud for "Do-Re-Mi," a song about learning how to sing the correct notes. It was such a special moment, not only to hear her sing but also to be able to sing with her. 

When you know the notes to sing, you truly can sing anything! ? 

Thank you to Leah's instructor Haley for recording this special moment!

#SingAlong

So many hearts came together, celebrated, shared stories, and raised crucial funds that will make a significant impact in the lives of the individuals we serve. Your collective generosity lights our way, enabling us to enrich lives through powerful connections with horses, animals, and nature. Thank you. ?

What is Main Stay’s horse herd fund? ? 
It takes a remarkable team of horses to support our riders, but the costs of purchasing and caring for them continue to rise. Main Stay’s Horse Fund plays a vital role in covering these essential expenses, from acquiring new program horses to ensuring the health and well-being of our horse herd. With your support, we can continue to provide our program services to as many individuals as possible.

Did you know that Main Stay is a registered Monarch Waystation? This means that we are a safe place for Monarch Butterflies to rest during their migration by maintaining a good habitat. Part of our goal in maintaining a good habitat for the butterflies includes our participation in the Illinois Monarch Pledge, where we have pledged to improve our native habitats and provide education on Monarch Butterflies. 

To continue our spread of education on environmental conservation, we were able to host a seminar with the McHenry County Conservation District on the Monarch Life Cycle! Participants learned about the journey and life cycle of Monarch Butterflies and were able to see how Main Stay helps to raise and release our own. 

Thank you, McHenry County Conservation District, for this opportunity and providing a great presentation!

In addition to our adaptive riding and horsemanship program, Main Stay offers shorter-term riding options for youth (ages 8-16) and active adults (55+) through our Saddle Up program. Each session lasts 4-6 weeks and includes groups of 3-4 participants who learn horsemanship and riding skills.

While Disability Pride Month is celebrated throughout July, today marks the 34th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). This landmark law prohibits discrimination against people with disabilities, paving the way for a more inclusive society, a great first step, however, there is still more work to be done. As we celebrate this day, it is crucial to recognize that discrimination and challenges still affect this diverse community. 

We hope you'll join us in continuing to create an environment where everyone feels valued and respected, recognizing the unique abilities that each individual brings and the beauty that emerges when those abilities shine. By working together, not just this month, but every month, we can help ensure that every person in our community is given the opportunity to thrive and the support to reach their highest potential.

#ADA34

See Me, For Me: Meet Patty!

Patty has been coming to Main Stay for six years, starting when she was a freshman at McHenry High School! She has graduated high school and continues her education with the Bridges program, which is a transitional program working towards independent living skills now that she is a young adult.

Patty participates in our Equine and Animal Assisted Learning program, where she comes to work on goals. One of her goals this session is to work on using her softer/quieter “inside” voice. She wants people to know that she is funny and silly, and she is always ready to start up a dance party! Carla, Main Stay's Animal Assisted Learning Manager, has worked with Patty a lot over the years, and is so impressed that Patty is eternally positive and kind to everyone around her, animals and people alike!

Learn more about Patty at: mainstayfarm.org/Patty

Last week, Main Stay partnered with The Land Conservancy of McHenry County for a weeding workday as part of their Conservation @Work program! Our wonderful garden volunteers cleaned up the native flower beds in front of the building and learned how to help native species prepare for the winter. Did you know that pollinating insects will nest in the stems of plants? 

Thank you to our awesome team of garden volunteers and to the Land Conservancy for helping us maintain our native plants! We look forward to more partnership opportunities! ?

Meet Kay, one of our beloved adaptive riding horses who's been with us for 11 years! Her breed is a Norwegian Fjord, originating from the mountains of Norway.

Fjords, as they are commonly known as, are an intelligent breed of horse that are both gentle, yet mighty! Their short, stocky build and calm demeanor makes them excellent adaptive riding horses, though they can excel in many other disciplines. 

Kay is brown dun in color, which means her body and mane are a light brown/cream color. However, there are five colors recognized by the breed standard. Dun-colored Fjords have primitive markings, including the dorsal stripe, which is a dark stripe running from the forelock to tail, and zebra-like striping on their legs and some on their withers. Their manes are very distinct with the black stripe down the middle and usually roached short to accentuate their curved, powerful necks. 

The Fjord is one of the world's oldest breeds, with their DNA dating back 4,000 years ago. They once served as Viking warhorses for their powerful movement and unflappable personalities, to later being used as valuable farm horses. In the early 1900's, an effort was made to restart the pure breeding of the Fjord with the stallion Njal, and today, all Fjord's can be traced back to him. Kay has a circle marking on her cheek, affectionately known as Njal Mark (as seen in the photo of Kay in her stall), tracing back to that stallion! 

Kay's unflappable attitude and surefootedness gives her riders great confidence in the saddle! ?

Did you know that annual dental work is essential for a horse’s health and well-being? 

Regular dental care is another important part in keeping our hard working equines comfortable and performing at their best! Even our miniature equine see Dr. Hunt and her awesome team from Midwest Veterinary Dental Services. This routine dental appointment helps to identify and fix issues before they become painful problems, ensuring our horses can eat and perform without discomfort. 

Horses are hypsodonts, meaning their teeth are continually erupting – about 1/8 of an inch a year! This type of teeth is common in mammals like horses and rabbits, who have a diet of coarse forages that wear down their enamel. Horses' upper portion of teeth are also wider than the bottom so this can often lead to uneven wear, which causes things like waves, sharp points and sharp edges called “hooks” to develop. Both reasons lend to why it is so important for equines to have proper and lifelong dentistry!

An annual oral exam is most effective when done under the sedation of a licensed veterinarian. This is to ensure that all parts of the mouth can be inspected including the teeth, tongue, and muscles. Equine dentists will even manipulate the jaw to replicate chewing to ensure proper contact across all teeth. During the procedure – called a “float” – they will utilize both battery powered rasps and manual hand rasps, a dental speculum to comfortably open the mouth (as pictured with King & Fern) and liquid antiseptic is used to flush out any debris. More serious procedures such as a tooth removal are done in a clinic instead of at the farm, where they can conduct dental x-rays and provide a more sterile environment under anesthesia. 

Without proper dental care, a horse can suffer from malnutrition, chronic pain, impaction, colic, unwanted behaviors, and tooth loss in older horses. A well-maintained mouth leads to better focus and performance in the arena or on the trail with our clients. Good dental hygiene is also closely linked to proper digestion and nutrition in horses. 

A healthy mouth means we can continue keeping our incredible herd of equines looking and feeling good here at Main Stay! 

#didyouknow #horsehealth
We are so grateful for this partnership! ?

At Main Stay, we understand the vital role that hoof care plays in the overall health and well-being of our incredible herd of horses. As part of International Hoof Care Week (January 21-24, 2025), we’re excited to share insights into how we approach hoof care and the thoughtful considerations that go into every decision we make for our herd!

Regular farrier care is crucial for horses, whether they are barefoot or a shod horse but how do we decide whether a horse will wear shoes or not? 

The decision to shoe a horse or keep them barefoot depends on various factors like their environment, job, and conformation. We work with our team of farriers and veterinarian to consider the following for every horse at Main Stay:

- Hoof structure and angles
- Physical body structure
- Sensitivities and comfort level
- Previous history
- Xray diagnostics

Our goal for our horses is to maintain a primarily barefoot herd due to the ability for more natural movement and the natural shock absorption properties, which in turn reduces joint strain in our horses, increasing the longevity of our working animals.

Often many of our incoming new horses may transition to barefoot. This can take approximately one month per year of previous shoeing, to create gradual changes. Even after transition barefoot horses still require regular farrier care to maintain healthy hooves. Our consistent schedule of every 6-8 weeks ensures proper balance, prevents overgrowth, and reduces the risk of potential injury. 

Asher is a great example of the trial and error that comes with hoof care. Asher came to us in shoes and while we tried to transition him to barefoot he made it clear to us he was more interested in the support the shoes he was used to offered him. 

For the short time he was barefoot we provided him additional protection through the use of HoofArmor. HoofArmor is a two-part epoxy that cures to the bottom of the hoof and is strong enough to stand up to abrasive surfaces and chipping but remain flexible enough to flex with the natural hoof movement and expansion. Additionally, we supplement his diet with NuHoof, which adds essential amino acids and biotin to his diet to provide even further support in his hoof health.

Ultimately, there’s NO one-size-fits-all answer. The best choice for each horse is highly dependent on their personal needs. Some horses thrive barefoot, while others benefit from the added protection and support of shoes. Regardless, regular farrier care is essential to the long-term health and fitness of any horse and to maintain optimal hoof health and function for a healthy and happy therapy horse here at Main Stay!

We simply have the BEST animal care team around! No matter the weather or how they feel, they show up to care for our herd of extraordinary animals. 

No working from home for them when the weather is frigid, or the roads are bad. They work extra hours when needed (and usually without being asked) to cover for each other or to take care of an animal who gets sick or injured “after hours.” 

Sometimes, it may seem like they have the best job around, but not on days like today. 

Many thanks from all of us (including the animals) for their loving care and dedication!

Setting Your Nonprofit Board Up for Success: practical tools, strategies and how horses teach us 

Are you ready to take your nonprofit board to the next level? Join Kathleen Terry-Sharp and Cindy Schwarz for an inspiring, hands-on workshop at the farm on Friday, February 21st, 9 AM – 12 PM! This hybrid pre-conference workshop combines practical strategies with the unique wisdom of horses to help you build stronger, more effective nonprofit boards.

Whether you’re a nonprofit leader, board member, or stakeholder, this workshop will give you actionable tools and a fresh perspective to strengthen your board’s performance and impact.

Online registration is required by February 7. To register, or for more information, please visit: https://lnkd.in/gJPnpAm8

This preconference workshop is offered as part of the PATH Intl. Region 7 Conference, but you do NOT need to attend the conference to participate in this workshop!

Sometimes it is hard to put into words how much teamwork goes into running an adaptive riding lesson, but we have a photo that captures it beautifully! 

This picture depicts a rider on their horse, alongside two side walkers and a leader. All of these beings share a connection between each other – the horse is connected to the leader through the lead rope, and the side walkers are connected to the rider by physical touch. But what is very special about this photo is that it shows a connection that goes beyond the boundaries of physical connection! The side walkers, the horse, and the leaders are all walking in unison. 

This moment is really special because it illustrates the essence of adaptive riding: a unified effort, enabling the rider to receive what they need from the lesson without even needing the direction of when to pick up their feet. It truly shows the transformative power of adaptive riding, where teamwork forms the backbone of a shared, uplifting experience.

As we kick off the first day of the winter adaptive riding session, we celebrate the connections and teamwork that make these lessons so special. Here’s to a great riding season ahead!

Today is National Save the Eagles Day, and we could not have planned a more perfect way to celebrate! Just yesterday, we were fortunate enough to witness, and capture a photo of, a bald eagle soaring directly over our farm. We are grateful for the conservation efforts that make moments like this possible, including our partnership with The Land Conservancy of McHenry County through a land easement.

Seeing a bald eagle in flight is a sight we will never take for granted here at the farm. 

#NationalSavetheEaglesDay
Lucy and Linus miss all of the volunteers and clients during the break! It has made them even more curious and playful in the grooming area.

Fun fact: Jasmin is our oldest goat at 12 years old!

She is an Oberhasli, and she looks very typical to the breed because they are always brown with black markings. The breed originates from Switzerland and is used as dairy goats. They were introduced to the United States in the early 1900s.

Jasmin loves to socialize with all of the herd and is accepting of everyone! She is a healthy eater who loves mealtimes, and she gets fed extra because of her age. Jasmin started her career of helping children by being a 4H goat, but because of a physical condition she is not the ideal for a dairy goat and would likely have ended up as a meat goat instead. Fortunately, an equine & animal assisted learning client was at the county fair, met Jasmin, and that special connection led her to Main Stay. She arrived at the farm in the backseat of the farm truck and fit right in with the herd! She can be found chewing her cud, enjoying her naps, and spending time with the other animals!

See Me, For Me: Meet Patty!

Patty has been coming to Main Stay for six years, starting when she was a freshman at McHenry High School! She has graduated high school and continues her education with the Bridges program, which is a transitional program working towards independent living skills now that she is a young adult.

Patty participates in our Equine and Animal Assisted Learning program, where she comes to work on goals. One of her goals this session is to work on using her softer/quieter “inside” voice. She wants people to know that she is funny and silly, and she is always ready to start up a dance party! Carla, Main Stay's Animal Assisted Learning Manager, has worked with Patty a lot over the years, and is so impressed that Patty is eternally positive and kind to everyone around her, animals and people alike!

At Main Stay, we understand the vital role that hoof care plays in the overall health and well-being of our incredible herd of horses. As part of International Hoof Care Week (January 21-24, 2025), we’re excited to share insights into how we approach hoof care and the thoughtful considerations that go into every decision we make for our herd!

Regular farrier care is crucial for horses, whether they are barefoot or a shod horse but how do we decide whether a horse will wear shoes or not? 

The decision to shoe a horse or keep them barefoot depends on various factors like their environment, job, and conformation. We work with our team of farriers and veterinarian to consider the following for every horse at Main Stay:

- Hoof structure and angles
- Physical body structure
- Sensitivities and comfort level
- Previous history
- Xray diagnostics

Our goal for our horses is to maintain a primarily barefoot herd due to the ability for more natural movement and the natural shock absorption properties, which in turn reduces joint strain in our horses, increasing the longevity of our working animals.

Often many of our incoming new horses may transition to barefoot. This can take approximately one month per year of previous shoeing, to create gradual changes. Even after transition barefoot horses still require regular farrier care to maintain healthy hooves. Our consistent schedule of every 6-8 weeks ensures proper balance, prevents overgrowth, and reduces the risk of potential injury. 

Asher is a great example of the trial and error that comes with hoof care. Asher came to us in shoes and while we tried to transition him to barefoot he made it clear to us he was more interested in the support the shoes he was used to offered him. 

For the short time he was barefoot we provided him additional protection through the use of HoofArmor. HoofArmor is a two-part epoxy that cures to the bottom of the hoof and is strong enough to stand up to abrasive surfaces and chipping but remain flexible enough to flex with the natural hoof movement and expansion. Additionally, we supplement his diet with NuHoof, which adds essential amino acids and biotin to his diet to provide even further support in his hoof health.

Ultimately, there’s NO one-size-fits-all answer. The best choice for each horse is highly dependent on their personal needs. Some horses thrive barefoot, while others benefit from the added protection and support of shoes. Regardless, regular farrier care is essential to the long-term health and fitness of any horse and to maintain optimal hoof health and function for a healthy and happy therapy horse here at Main Stay!

We simply have the BEST animal care team around! No matter the weather or how they feel, they show up to care for our herd of extraordinary animals. 

No working from home for them when the weather is frigid, or the roads are bad. They work extra hours when needed (and usually without being asked) to cover for each other or to take care of an animal who gets sick or injured “after hours.” 

Sometimes, it may seem like they have the best job around, but not on days like today. 

Many thanks from all of us (including the animals) for their loving care and dedication!

Sometimes it is hard to put into words how much teamwork goes into running an adaptive riding lesson, but we have a photo that captures it beautifully! 

This picture depicts a rider on their horse, alongside two side walkers and a leader. All of these beings share a connection between each other – the horse is connected to the leader through the lead rope, and the side walkers are connected to the rider by physical touch. But what is very special about this photo is that it shows a connection that goes beyond the boundaries of physical connection! The side walkers, the horse, and the leaders are all walking in unison. 

This moment is really special because it illustrates the essence of adaptive riding: a unified effort, enabling the rider to receive what they need from the lesson without even needing the direction of when to pick up their feet. It truly shows the transformative power of adaptive riding, where teamwork forms the backbone of a shared, uplifting experience.

As we kick off the first day of the winter adaptive riding session, we celebrate the connections and teamwork that make these lessons so special. Here’s to a great riding season ahead!

Today is National Save the Eagles Day, and we could not have planned a more perfect way to celebrate! Just yesterday, we were fortunate enough to witness, and capture a photo of, a bald eagle soaring directly over our farm. We are grateful for the conservation efforts that make moments like this possible, including our partnership with The Land Conservancy of McHenry County through a land easement.

Seeing a bald eagle in flight is a sight we will never take for granted here at the farm. 

#NationalSavetheEaglesDay
Lucy and Linus miss all of the volunteers and clients during the break! It has made them even more curious and playful in the grooming area.

Fun fact: Jasmin is our oldest goat at 12 years old!

She is an Oberhasli, and she looks very typical to the breed because they are always brown with black markings. The breed originates from Switzerland and is used as dairy goats. They were introduced to the United States in the early 1900s.

Jasmin loves to socialize with all of the herd and is accepting of everyone! She is a healthy eater who loves mealtimes, and she gets fed extra because of her age. Jasmin started her career of helping children by being a 4H goat, but because of a physical condition she is not the ideal for a dairy goat and would likely have ended up as a meat goat instead. Fortunately, an equine & animal assisted learning client was at the county fair, met Jasmin, and that special connection led her to Main Stay. She arrived at the farm in the backseat of the farm truck and fit right in with the herd! She can be found chewing her cud, enjoying her naps, and spending time with the other animals!

March is Developmental Disabilities Awareness Month, and this year's theme, "We're Here All Year," says it all.

Individuals with developmental disabilities are not just part of our community one month out of the year; they are the community, every single day.

When individuals with developmental disabilities are given the space to grow, connect, and contribute, the results simply speak for themselves. At the farm, we witness this every day in our programs. Through their unique abilities, they bring creativity, insight, resilience, and joy— not only to our farm but to the entire community.

Awareness is NOT just a month-long campaign. It is an ongoing commitment to ensuring our spaces, programs, and mindsets are inclusive all year-round. It means recognizing that social-emotional learning, connection, and support are not extras… they are essentials. 

Because when everyone is empowered to reach their full potential, we all thrive. ?

About The Communicator Awards
The Communicator Awards recognizes excellence, effectiveness and innovation across all areas of communication. For 31 years, the platform has provided an equal opportunity for companies, agencies, organizations and independent creators to be honored, regardless of team size or project budget.

See Me, For Me: Leah

Leah has been riding at Main Stay for nearly 37 years - a journey that began when she was just seven years old. Now at 44, she continues to ride in our Adaptive Riding program, with the same joy and determination.
Over the past year, she has made big strides in strength and communication, even returning to trotting again during her lessons. Her instructor Haley shared:

“I have loved watching Leah get stronger over the past year! She is strong enough to stay centered and balanced enough that we have been able to trot again during lessons! Leah has also been talking more, letting the leader know the color of the next pole or cone and even letting us know who is singing next in The Lion King! I'm excited that the weather is getting nice again, because she loves to ride outside and steer Harry over the tracks!"

Despite the frustration of not always being able to express herself verbally, it is the kindness and love that Leah receives that keeps her moving to new heights. Like her favorite Disney princesses, Leah carries a magic all her own - a spirit that speaks louder than words ever could.

Learn more about Leah, and see her, for her at: https://lnkd.in/deHYFJQA

Additionally, things can be hidden inside them so they provide a purposeful way to engage with fine motor skills in the arena – opening/closing doors, pulling things out and utilizing those objects in their lesson such as balls to throw in the basketball hoop, grooming tools to learn about, bean bags to throw etc.

Thank you, Lauren and Denise! ?

Triple Crown Raffle tickets are NOW ON SALE! https://lnkd.in/gXxg-jiM

This year, you could win $7,500 in cash ?no restrictions, no limits, no joke! Just cash in your pocket. 

The best part? We are offering an April Fools’ Day special: TODAY ONLY, buy one ticket and get a second at half price – this is NOT a joke! This special is limited to the first 200 tickets sold – and tickets are selling fast!

Learn more about the Triple Crown Raffle at: https://lnkd.in/ggivGJaR
Every ticket helps empower the children and adults that we serve to reach their highest potential through the infinite restorative abilities of horses, animals and nature, while helping to keep our services accessible to those who need them most.

March is Developmental Disabilities Awareness Month, and this year's theme, "We're Here All Year," says it all.

Individuals with developmental disabilities are not just part of our community one month out of the year; they are the community, every single day.

When individuals with developmental disabilities are given the space to grow, connect, and contribute, the results simply speak for themselves. At the farm, we witness this every day in our programs. Through their unique abilities, they bring creativity, insight, resilience, and joy— not only to our farm but to the entire community.

Awareness is NOT just a month-long campaign. It is an ongoing commitment to ensuring our spaces, programs, and mindsets are inclusive all year-round. It means recognizing that social-emotional learning, connection, and support are not extras… they are essentials. 

Because when everyone is empowered to reach their full potential, we all thrive. ?

Become a sponsor today at: https://lnkd.in/ggyZZrQs

Sponsoring this event allows business leaders to show their support for Main Stay’s vital programs while connecting with hundreds of community members who share a passion for our mission. Your partnership helps ensure that our services remain accessible to those who need them most.

We are thrilled to announce that Main Stay has been recognized at the 31st Annual Communicator Awards with an Award of Excellence for Kay's Holiday Card! 

Presented by the Academy of Interactive & Visual Arts (AIVA), the Communicator Awards is one of the largest and most competitive programs honoring excellence in marketing, communication, and creative work. We are incredibly proud that Kay’s Holiday Card was celebrated alongside entries from organizations such as NASA+, Netflix, Apple, and The Walt Disney Company. It is a true honor to be recognized among such respected industry leaders.

We are especially proud to recognize the creative talents behind the card: Randi Murawski, Main Stay’s Communications Manager, who thoughtfully designed and crafted the card’s message, and Haley Cronin, one of our dedicated Instructors, who took the beautiful photos of Kay in the snow. Their collaboration captured Kay’s winter spirit in a way that clearly resonated far and wide!

To view the full list of winners and learn more about the competition, please visit: https://lnkd.in/g4e4XhV2

***
About The Communicator Awards
The Communicator Awards recognizes excellence, effectiveness and innovation across all areas of communication. For 31 years, the platform has provided an equal opportunity for companies, agencies, organizations and independent creators to be honored, regardless of team size or project budget. 
The awards are judged by the Academy of Interactive & Visual Arts (AIVA), an invitation-only body of over 500 industry leaders from top brands and agencies. This year’s Jury included professionals from Google, Accenture Song, Smithsonian, Microsoft, Digitas, JPMorgan Chase & Co., Publicis, Spotify, Johns Hopkins, Critical Mass, Amazon, The Andy Warhol Museum and many more. For more, visit aiva.org.

If you missed the segment this morning, you can watch it here: https://lnkd.in/gqExaKr6

See Me, For Me: Leah

Leah has been riding at Main Stay for nearly 37 years - a journey that began when she was just seven years old. Now at 44, she continues to ride in our Adaptive Riding program, with the same joy and determination.
Over the past year, she has made big strides in strength and communication, even returning to trotting again during her lessons. Her instructor Haley shared:

“I have loved watching Leah get stronger over the past year! She is strong enough to stay centered and balanced enough that we have been able to trot again during lessons! Leah has also been talking more, letting the leader know the color of the next pole or cone and even letting us know who is singing next in The Lion King! I'm excited that the weather is getting nice again, because she loves to ride outside and steer Harry over the tracks!"

Despite the frustration of not always being able to express herself verbally, it is the kindness and love that Leah receives that keeps her moving to new heights. Like her favorite Disney princesses, Leah carries a magic all her own - a spirit that speaks louder than words ever could.

Learn more about Leah, and see her, for her at: https://lnkd.in/deHYFJQA

Main Stay, a fieldwork site for Occupational Therapy Assistant (OTA) students from McHenry County College, welcomes students to the farm in April for one of their clinical rotations. April also happens to be Occupational Therapy Month, a time to recognize OT's and OTA's as they help people participate in meaningful activities. 

Students meet riders and their families, observe and help in classes and learn how impactful riding is for our clients here at the farm and in their everyday lives as they work to achieve their goals. The farm provides a wonderful non-traditional learning environment to see first-hand the value in meaningful activities such as riding, working on life skills and gardening.

#OccupationalTherapyMonth

We want to give a big THANK YOU to our talented rider Lauren and dedicated volunteer Denise J. for painting these beautiful mailboxes for our riders to use in the arena! 

These mailboxes aren’t just cute, they are a wonderful teaching tool and they have a few purposes.

Riders use these as visuals to work on steering and stopping/starting changes of pace. Additionally, things can be hidden inside them so they provide a purposeful way to engage with fine motor skills in the arena – opening/closing doors, pulling things out and utilizing those objects in their lesson such as balls to throw in the basketball hoop, grooming tools to learn about, bean bags to throw etc.

Thank you, Lauren and Denise! ?

Happy National Sunflower Day! ?

Sunflowers remind us to grow with purpose, face the light, and keep reaching -- even on cloudy days. At Main Stay, we see that same spirit in those we serve. Like sunflowers, they turn toward possibility and never stop reaching toward what’s possible.

“Keep your face always toward the sunshine, and the shadows will fall behind you.” — Walt Whitman

See Me, For Me: Meet Erin!

If you have spent time around the farm, chances are you have seen Erin -- she has been riding at Main Stay for 30 years! When she is at the farm, Erin looks forward to riding her horse, Kay, outside on nice weather days. Trotting is her favorite as Erin has a definite need for speed!

Right now, Erin is working toward a big goal: holding the reins to steer and stop Kay on her own. It's not always easy though. Keeping her posture straight while managing the reins can be challenging and, at times, frustrating. But Erin’s determination does not waver. In fact, her proudest moments are when she accomplishes things all by herself! Her instructor Mikki shared:

"Erin always gives her best when she shows up to ride! You can really see her dedication to riding and she always pushes herself to grow. She also has a big heart and always asks how everyone is doing, who someone new is, and where a team member is if they aren't there that day. She also knows every Disney song and will proudly sing the best lines when we play music in class! It's an honor to teach and learn from Erin and her class is always a bright part of the day!"

When she is not at the farm, you might find Erin enjoying one of her favorite hobbies, bowling! She also scuba dives and is an excellent swimmer. But above all, there is one thing Erin wishes everyone knew about her: she can be really silly!

Whether she is reaching her goals in the arena or zooming around in her orange power chair, Erin is a joyful reminder that determination can help us overcome even the toughest challenges, while still being silly along the way.
Learn more about Erin, and see her, for her at: https://lnkd.in/gJB3JxxF

During the segment, we will be sharing the incredible benefits of all programs at the farm—adaptive riding, equine and animal-assisted learning, and gardening—and how our special animals and beautiful land impact the lives of Meridian's clients and everyone who comes to the farm.

Main Stay received two grants from Meridian Health to bring Equine and Animal Assisted Learning programs to their youth and senior clients and gather data on how animal-assisted learning improves mental health.

Main Stay is incredibly proud to be a sponsor of HLC Therapy Group’s Disability Pride Event 2025, the first event of its kind in the Chicago suburbs.

At Main Stay, supporting Disability Pride is more than a sponsorship to us, it is a reflection of our core values: celebrating individuals for who they are, supporting how they want to grow, and empowering people of all abilities. 

Hosted by Downtown Crystal Lake, this celebration honors the beauty, diversity, and lived experiences of people with disabilities. All are invited to join the celebration this Saturday, July 26, from 11 AM to 1 PM in the Grant Street Parking Lot. This free event will include performers, local vendors, and resource booths, highlighting the diverse voices within the disability community. This Saturday also marks the 35th anniversary of the passing of the federal Americans with Disabilities Act.

For more information, please visit https://lnkd.in/gAKUCgum
